article.text: Saturday April 14 2012 Syrian troops have shelled two rebel-held areas of the central city of Homs in an apparent violation of an internationally brokered ceasefire, activists said. The reports came two days after the truce brokered by international envoy Kofi Annan went into effect. The violence in Syria since then has been much less than the daily norm of clashes and shellings before the ceasefire. The regime restricts access of foreign observers, including journalists, making it difficult to verify reports of violence independently. The Britain-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights said the shelling lasted for about an hour but there were no reports of casualties. Activist Tarek Badrakhan, who is based in the rebel-held Khaldiyeh area of Homs, and the Observatory said the shelling targeted the Jouret el-Shayah and Qarabees areas. The shelling in Homs came as the United Nations Security Council prepared to vote on a resolution authorising the deployment of the first wave of UN military observers to monitor the ceasefire between the Syrian government and opposition fighters. The truce is at the centre of Mr Annan's peace plan, which is aimed at ending more than a year of bloodshed that, according to the UN, has killed more than 9,000 people. The plans then aims to launch inclusive Syrian-led talks on the country's political future. The uprising began last year with mostly peaceful protests against the Assad family dynasty, which has ruled Syria for more than four decades. But the government's violent crackdown fuelled an armed insurgency as army defectors and protesters began fighting back. On Friday, Syrian forces used live fire, tear gas and clubs to beat back tens of thousands of protesters who took to the streets across the country in powerful and often jubilant displays of defiance. The Local Co-ordination Committees activist group said there were 771 demonstrations throughout Syria, a number that is larger the protests of the weeks before.
